title: Will fractional shares attract a younger investor crowd?
text:
Generational inequality has left baby boomers in clover while their children — or children’s children — eke out their lives in rented flats with only the occasional slice of avocado toast for consolation.

This creates a problem for brokers, especially when single stocks have steep price labels: where to find the next generation of investors. Fractional trading is the solution, according to Charles Schwab, the big US execution-only broker.

It plans to offer trading in fractions of popular equities. The investor might, for example, buy one 10th of a share in Amazon (sticker price $1765) for a mere $176. If they feel like splashing out, they could perhaps acquire a half share for $884.

Older clients may be richer, but they also have a propensity to die soon. Charles Schwab needs to cultivate clients from among millennials who are now in their mid-30s. Sooner or later, some of them will have real money.

A few already do. They own employee shares in big tech companies. But these businesses have contributed to the unaffordability of equities for those outside their gilded realm. The tech sector has propelled the US market upwards.

At the same time, the stock splits once undertaken by companies in the cause of “marketability” have fallen from fashion. Prices have become more volatile, reflecting the rise of algorithmic trading.
description: The bragging rights attached to a third of a Google share are negligible. Millennials, noting that the market may be at a cyclical peak, may find avocado toast a more satisfying investment.
